name: The Final Countdown! Quiz | By The Numbers | 10 Questions

questions.text: Ten!  In the song "The Twelve Days of Christmas", what did "my true love" give on the tenth day?
questions.explanation:
Lords-a-leaping.

	"The Twelve Days of Christmas" was an English carol written in 1780. The song has gone through several variations from a Biblical version to a "redneck" version.

questions.text: Nine!  Dante's "Divine Comedy" lists the nine circles of Hell. Which one of the following is NOT listed as a circle of Hell?
questions.explanation:
Impatience.

	The nine circles of Hell are limbo, lust, greed, gluttony, violence, treachery, heresy, fraud, and anger. Dante wrote "Divine Comedy" in the 14th century as a poem. He described hell as having nine circles of suffering.

questions.text: Eight!  The Section Eight program is known as the Housing Choice Voucher Program for what United States department?
questions.explanation:
HUD.

	Housing and Urban Development was started in 1965 by Lyndon Johnson to help with housing. The Section Eight policy of the Housing Act was written before HUD even started. The policy offers money to landlords on behalf of low-income households.

questions.text: Seven!  The number seven jersey was retired from the New York Yankees in honor of which Hall of Fame center fielder?
questions.explanation:
Mickey Mantle.

	Mickey Mantle played his entire career for the New York Yankees. His Major League Baseball career began with the New York Yankees on April 17, 1951 and ended on September 28, 1968.

questions.text: Six!  Which star of the NBC drama "Parenthood" was also on the HBO series "Six Feet Under"?
questions.explanation:
Peter Krause.

	Peter Krause starred as Nate Fisher in the HBO series "Six Feet Under" as the owner of a funeral home. In the NBC drama "Parenthood", Peter starred as Adam Braverman, the father of three, and the oldest son of Zeek and Camille Braverman.

questions.text: Five!  To what does the Fifth Amendment of the US Constitution regard?
questions.explanation:
Freedom against self-incrimination.

	The Fifth Amendment of the US Constitution says that a person has the right not to incriminate themselves or be tried a second time for a crime that was committed. The Fifth Amendment also says that private property can't be taken away unless it is paid for (i.e., " without just compensation").

questions.text: Four!  Which singer's fourth studio album was aptly titled "4"?
questions.explanation:
Beyonce Knowles.

	Beyonce Knowles' fourth studio album was sent out on June 24, 2011 through Columbia Records. Her fourth studio album contained eight tracks (US original release version). Five songs on the album became radio singles.

questions.text: Three!  In bowling, what is three strikes in a row known as?
questions.explanation:
Turkey.

	In bowling, if two strikes are made consecutively it is known as a double. Three consecutive strikes are known as a turkey. Four consecutive strikes are known as a yahtzee.

questions.text: Two!  The number two is the atomic number for what gas?
questions.explanation:
Helium.

	An atomic number of two means that helium has two protons in the nucleus of its atom.  Helium is the second lightest element and second most abundant element in the universe.  Helium is a colorless and odorless gas that is known as one of the noble gases on the periodic table.

questions.text: One!  Which author started the Stephanie Plum series with the first book "One for the Money"?
questions.explanation:
Janet Evanovich.

	Before starting the Plum series, Janet Evanovich was the author of eleven books. To gather information for her new series, Janet worked with bail enforcement agencies and police departments to garner information for the series. The first book in the series, "One for the Money", was published in 1994. In January 2012, "One for the Money" was released as a movie starring Katherine Heigl as Stephanie Plum.
